test of strict scrutiny is nearly impossible to satisfy. It is not hard to show that
a piece of legislation has some chance of serving some legitimate goal and,
thus, passes the rational relation test. It is difficult to show that the purpose
of a law is compelling—that is, of overwhelming importance; and it is even
more difficult to show that the stated purpose cannot be achieved by any less
intrusive means. Thus, in adopting this new test, the Court no longer showed
